table-wrap.anchoringText: Case 1 is an example of frac fluid (Table 1) and hydrocarbon (Table 2) tracers being utilized to show the effects of existing faults intersecting a wellbore. There was little indication during the hydraulic fracture stimulation that traced segments 7 and 8 were treated differently than the surrounding segments. Post-frac flowback/production fluid tracer analyses indicated that these zones were not contributing into the wellbore flow stream (Figure 2).
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Frac Fluid Tracers - Identifying Faults

table-wrap.anchoringText: Case 1 is an example of frac fluid (Table 1) and hydrocarbon (Table 2) tracers being utilized to show the effects of existing faults intersecting a wellbore. There was little indication during the hydraulic fracture stimulation that traced segments 7 and 8 were treated differently than the surrounding segments. Post-frac flowback/production fluid tracer analyses indicated that these zones were not contributing into the wellbore flow stream (Figure 2).
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Hydrocarbon Fluid Tracers - Identifying Faults

table-wrap.anchoringText: The lessons learned resulted in abandoning stages across known faults that resulted in zero or minimal flowback/production (Figure 3 and Figure 4). Some effects are still observed in this example as shown in Table 3 specifically in traced segments 18 to 15 and 14 to 13 which are on either side of the known fault. After approximately two weeks, flowback/production was finally achieved from these intervals once the wellbore bottomhole pressures were reduced. This type of study led to lower completion costs by bypassing zones that were unproductive.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Frac Fluid Tracers - Identifying Faults

table-wrap.anchoringText: Case 2 utilizes unique frac fluid (Table 5) and hydrocarbon fluid (Table 6) tracers across 12 stages of a 13- stage planned fracture stimulation. Stage 8 was not stimulated due to the presence of an observed fracture on the well log. As the samples were taken, it was observed that the heel stages (traced segments 10 to 13) were lagging in flowback/production throughout the 115 days of sampling. A review of the available geologic data indicated that the heel portion of the lateral showed more natural fractures than the remaining portion of the lateral and that it was slightly depleted by a combination of increased permeability from the natural fractures and nearby existing vertical wellbores.
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Frac Fluid Tracers - High Permeability
